events.event_description: U.S. working natural gas inventories ended the winter heating season at 2,290 billion cubic feet, 39% above the five-year average.
events.citation: U.S. working natural gas inventories ended the winter heating season (November 1–March 31) at 2,290 billion cubic feet (Bcf), 39% more than the previous five-year (2019–23) average.

events.event_description: The United States experienced its warmest winter on record, leading to significantly reduced natural gas consumption.
events.citation: According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), the United States just experienced its warmest winter on record.

events.event_description: December 2023 was the warmest December on record in many U.S. locations, with Northeast and Midwest consumption dropping 23% compared to December 2022.
events.citation: According to NOAA, December 2023 was the warmest December on record in many U.S. locations, particularly in the northern and central United States, where most households use natural gas for space heating. In the Northeast and Midwest, natural gas consumption in the residential and commercial sectors in December 2023 averaged 20 billion cubic feet per day (Bcf/d), 23% lower than December 2022

events.event_description: U.S. dry natural gas production reached a record high of 107 Bcf/d in December 2023.
events.citation: Dry natural gas production averaged 106 Bcf/d in November and 107 Bcf/d in December—a record high.

events.event_description: Natural gas producers announced production curtailments and capital expenditure reductions due to low prices.
events.citation: In February and March, several producers, reacting to low natural gas prices, announced current or planned curtailments to production or reductions in capital expenditures toward natural gas-directed activities in 2024.

events.event_description: Henry Hub natural gas price fell to $1.50/MMBtu by the end of March 2024, with inventories 640 Bcf above the five-year average.
events.citation: By the end of March, inventories were 640 Bcf higher than the previous five-year average, and the Henry Hub price had fallen to $1.50/MMBtu, generally in line with the relationship between inventories and price.
